page.title: 03THE CUT OFF CHANNEL
page.content: A striking feature of the landscape of the Eastern Fens is the Cut off Channel. This embanked artificial river was constructed in the 1950s to lessen the risk of floods such as those which flooded the Fens during l912, l947 and 1953. The purpose of the channel is to divert the headwaters of the rivers Lark, Little Ouse and Wissey direct to the Great Ouse at Denver Sluice, rather than allowing them to overflow their banks in passing through those parts of the Fens which lie below sea level. The channel can also be used to take water in the opposite direction to supply the domestic needs of Essex.
